Does anyone what happened to all those swords that were confiscated at the
=
end of the war?=A0 There must have been thousands taken.=A0 Were they
destr=
oyed?=A0 Brought back to the US?=A0 Mccarthy's basement?
=A0
Mark

-----Ori=
ginal Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@=
yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of sigp210
Sent: Thursday, January 05, 2006 1:32 =
PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: SERIAL NUMB=
ERS ON JAPANESE SWORDS


I'd just like to add that the serial numbered swor=
ds are limited to
the NCO shin guntos with aluminium cast handle. I have se=
en many other
so-called Japanese swords with serial numbers on the blade, a=
nd these
were almost all Chinese fakes. For some reason, they think this
in=
creases the value or legitimacy.
After the war, most of the civilian swords=
 (bar a few identified as
art objects) were confiscated, not registered.
Th=
ere is very little chance of tracking down the original owners or
history o=
f 99% of these swords.

Regards,
Brian

>
> Hello David -
>
> Welcome and H=
appy 2006 to you too.
>
> If you have a sword with a serial number stamped =
on it (on the
blade) then you have a mass produced so-called "factory made"=
 sword.
Sometimes you will find some numbers stamped on the nakago (tang) o=
f a
sword, usually two or three digits, which in that case might relate to
=
"assembly" numbers; these same numbers are often repeated on seppa,
tsuba, =
etc. Swords were "registered" after the war and continue to be
so today, bu=
t the Japanese government never required anything
(registration numbers) to=
 be stamped on swords.
>
> Ron
> STL
